articles.headline: Businesswoman’s Fate a Test of China’s Resolve on North Korea
articles.snippet: The fate of Ma Xiaohong, and the business empire she built on trade with North Korea, has become a measure of China’s willingness to confront its neighbor.
articles.abstract: The fate of Ma Xiaohong, and the business empire she built on trade with North Korea, has become a measure of China’s willingness to confront its neighbor.
articles.lead_paragraph: DANDONG, China — Not long ago, Ma Xiaohong was the public face of China’s trade with North Korea.

articles.headline: Wielding Data, Women Force a Reckoning Over Bias in the Economics Field
articles.snippet: Longstanding complaints about the barriers women face in the economics profession are beginning to resonate within the male-dominated field.
articles.abstract: Longstanding complaints about the barriers women face in the economics profession are beginning to resonate within the male-dominated field.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — It is not difficult to find an all-male panel at the annual January mega-gathering of American economists. They are as common as PowerPoint presentations and pie charts. One such panel this year met to sleepily critique President Trump’s economic policies, but it was overshadowed by another panel, two ballrooms away, that jolted a profession that prides itself on cool rationality.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Noam Scheiber

articles.headline: Canada Attacks U.S. Tariffs by Taking Case to World Trade Organization
articles.snippet: A sweeping challenge to the Trump administration’s “America First” policies could add to tensions already frayed by Nafta negotiations.
articles.abstract: A sweeping challenge to the Trump administration’s “America First” policies could add to tensions already frayed by Nafta negotiations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Canada has filed a sweeping trade case against the United States at the World Trade Organization, lobbing a diplomatic grenade at the Trump administration’s “America First” approach amid an increasingly embattled trade relationship between the longstanding North American allies.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Ian Austen

articles.headline: To Grease Wheels of Congress, Trump Suggests Bringing Back Pork
articles.snippet: President Trump’s suggestion that Congress revive the old practice of salting spending bills with lawmaker pet projects has revived a simmering debate.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s suggestion that Congress revive the old practice of salting spending bills with lawmaker pet projects has revived a simmering debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Remember the infamous “Bridge to Nowhere”? The Montana Sheep Institute or the now-shuttered North Carolina teapot hall of fame?

articles.headline: Investors Spooked at Specter of Central Banks Halting Bond-Buying Spree
articles.snippet: The most immediate fear: A sharp falloff in bond prices would rattle equity markets that are now trading at record highs.
articles.abstract: The most immediate fear: A sharp falloff in bond prices would rattle equity markets that are now trading at record highs.
articles.lead_paragraph: For nearly a decade, central banks around the world have been the biggest buyers of bonds, sending interest rates plummeting and stock markets soaring.

articles.headline: What ‘Dreamers’ Say About the Great Immigration Debate
articles.snippet: Hundreds of thousands of immigrants are watching anxiously as judges and lawmakers jockey over policy.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of thousands of immigrants are watching anxiously as judges and lawmakers jockey over policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: With jitters and with prayers, with countdown clocks in their heads and their immigration lawyers on speed-dial, hundreds of thousands of young immigrants have spent all fall and winter watching President Trump and congressional leaders negotiate their fate, every fleck of news a tantalizing omen.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee, Caitlin Dickerson and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Purge of Kevin Spacey Gives ‘All the Money in the World’ a Pay Problem
articles.snippet: Mark Wahlberg received $1.5 million for reshoots of the kidnapping drama after it cut out the disgraced Spacey. Michelle Williams got just a small per diem.
articles.abstract: Mark Wahlberg received $1.5 million for reshoots of the kidnapping drama after it cut out the disgraced Spacey. Michelle Williams got just a small per diem.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The kidnapping drama “All the Money in the World” has become a new flash point in the debate over gender equality in Hollywood.

articles.headline: House Republicans’ Hard-Line Immigration Stand Clashes With Trump Overture
articles.snippet: A new proposal from House Republicans underscored how deep the divisions are between and within the two parties on immigration — just days before a deadline for a deal.
articles.abstract: A new proposal from House Republicans underscored how deep the divisions are between and within the two parties on immigration — just days before a deadline for a deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prominent House Republicans stepped forward on Wednesday with a vision of immigration policy that clashed fiercely with President Trump’s recent overtures of bipartisanship and highlighted how difficult it will be for Congress and the president to reach accord in the coming weeks.
articles.byline: By Thomas Kaplan and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Trump Administration Says States May Impose Work Requirements for Medicaid
articles.snippet: Federal officials said they would support state efforts to require able-bodied adults to work as a condition of eligibility for Medicaid.
articles.abstract: Federal officials said they would support state efforts to require able-bodied adults to work as a condition of eligibility for Medicaid.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration said on Thursday that it would allow states to impose work requirements in Medicaid, a major policy shift that moves toward fulfilling a conservative vision for one of the nation’s largest social insurance programs for low-income people.

articles.headline: Walmart’s Bumpy Day: From Wage Increase to Store Closings
articles.snippet: The company cited the new tax law in announcing better pay and benefits, immersing itself in the partisan debate over tax policy. Then it closed 63 stores.
articles.abstract: The company cited the new tax law in announcing better pay and benefits, immersing itself in the partisan debate over tax policy. Then it closed 63 stores.
articles.lead_paragraph: Walmart, the nation’s largest private employer, waded into the bumpy waters of partisan politics on Thursday, announcing that it will use some of its savings under the new tax bill to provide wage increases, bonuses and expanded benefits to its hourly workers.

articles.headline: House Extends Surveillance Law, Rejecting New Privacy Safeguards
articles.snippet: House lawmakers voted to preserve the National Security Agency’s warrantless surveillance program.
articles.abstract: House lawmakers voted to preserve the National Security Agency’s warrantless surveillance program.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House of Representatives voted on Thursday to extend the National Security Agency’s warrantless surveillance program for six years with minimal changes, rejecting a push by a bipartisan group of lawmakers to impose significant privacy limits when it sweeps up Americans’ emails and other personal communications.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage, Eileen Sullivan and Nicholas Fandos
